questions.text: As per FAB classification, what percentage of blast cells in bone marrow biopsy is required to diagnose a patient with acute leukaemia?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) 30%

Explanation:

According to the FAB classification, 30% of blast cells must be present in the bone marrow and peripheral smear to diagnose acute leukaemia.

Classification for diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukaemia:

¬†

WHO classification

FAB (French-American-British) classification

Basis of classification

It incorporates genetics, immunophenotypic, and morphological features.

It is primarily based on morphology and cytochemistry

Subtypes
  • B-cell ALL, NOS (not otherwise specified).
  • B-cell ALL with recurrent genetic abnormalities.
  • T-cell ALL.
  • ALL-L1- small uniform cells
  • ALL-L2- large cells with irregular nuclei
  • ALL-L3- large cells with regular nuclei

Prognostic information

It provides prognostic information based on genetic abnormalities.

Limited prognostic information and focused on morphology.

Clinical utility

Used for diagnosis, treatment, and prognostication.

Less commonly used in clinical practice and more historical.

Diagnosis threshold

>20% blasts in the bone marrow.

>30% blasts in the bone marrow.

¬†

questions.text: Which is not included in the FAB classification of acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) L3 subtype?

choices.text: Presence of lymphoblasts with vacuoles and cytoplasmic blebs

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B)¬†Expression of surface immunoglobulins

Explanation:

Unlike Burkitt lymphoma cells, which typically express surface immunoglobulins, the lymphoblasts in ALL L3 subtype do not express surface immunoglobulins. Instead, they express other markers, such as CD10 and CD19.

FAB classification of ALL:

¬†

L1

L2

L3

Occurrence

More common

-

Less common

Morphology

Small homogenous blasts

Large heterogenous blasts

Large homogenous blasts

Cytoplasm

Scant blue

Moderately weak basophilic

Abundant basophilic with prominent vacuoles

Nucleus

Regular

Irregular nuclear outlines

-

Nucleoli

Small & indistinct

Prominent

-

Chromatin

Coarse & dark purple

Pink

-

Prognosis

Best

-

Poor

¬†

ALL-L3 is similar to Burkitt‚Äôs lymphoma. The image below shows the FAB types of ALL.

Presence of lymphoblasts with vacuoles and cytoplasmic blebs (Option A): The presence of lymphoblasts with vacuoles and cytoplasmic blebs is a characteristic feature of L3 subtype ALL.

Association with Epstein-Barr virus (Option C):

  • Burkitt lymphoma is strongly associated with Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) infection.
  • However, while EBV infection may be present in some ALL cases, it is not a defining characteristic of the ALL L3 subtype.

t(9;22) Philadelphia chromosome (Option D):

  • The Philadelphia chromosome, resulting from the translocation t(9;22), is associated with a different subtype of ALL (Philadelphia chromosome-positive ALL, or Ph+ ALL) rather than the L3 subtype.
  • Ph+ ALL is characterised by the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene (190 kDa fusion protein).

¬†

¬†

¬†

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) regarding chromosomes?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D)¬†t(15;17)

Explanation:

t(15;17) translocation is not associated with ALL; rather, it is seen in acute promyelocytic leukaemia (APML), a type of acute myeloid leukaemia, where t(15;17) translocation leads to the formation of a PML-RARùõº fusion protein¬†(Option D).

Genetic abnormalities associated with ALL:

  • B-cell ALL with recurrent cytogenetic abnormalities:
    • t(12;21): ETV6-RUNX1 (25% of the cases) (Option B ruled out).
    • t(v,11) (KMT2A-MLL).
    • t(9;22): BCR-ABL1¬†(Option A ruled out).
      • It produces a 190 kDa fusion protein.
    • t(5;14): IgH-IL3.
    • B-cell ALL with hyperdiploidy.
    • B-cell ALL with hypodiploidy.
    • B-cell ALL t(1;19): TCF3-PBX1. (Option C ruled out).
    • BCR-ABL1 like ALL (provisional entity in 2018 WHO).
    • iAMP 21 ALL.
  • T-cell ALL: NOTCH1 mutations are most common (50-70% of the cases).

¬†

questions.text: A 4-year-old male presents with fever, bleeding gums, and fatigue for 5 days. CBC shows Hb of 8g%, TLC 30,000/¬µL, and platelet count of 40,000/¬µL. A differential count shows an increased number of immature white blood cells. A bone marrow aspiration is done, as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B)¬†Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia.

Explanation:¬†

The clinical presentation of fatigue, fever, and bleeding gums, along with anaemia, thrombocytopenia, leukocytosis with a high proportion of immature white blood cells, and bone marrow aspirate showing lymphoblasts (numerous large cells with a high nucleus-to-cytoplasm ratio, round to oval nuclei, fine, dispersed chromatin pattern with scant, basophilic cytoplasm) is indicative of acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL).

Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia:

  • Neoplasms of immature B (pre-B) or T (pre-T) cells (known as lymphoblasts).
  • It is the most common cancer among children.
  • Peak incidence: 3rd year.
  • Clinical features: Abrupt stormy onset.

Symptoms

  • Due to decline in normal marrow function.
  • Fatigue - anaemia.
  • Infections - neutropenia.
  • Bleeding - thrombocytopenia

Mass effects

  • Bone pain due to marrow expansion and infiltration of the subperiosteum.
  • Generalised lymphadenopathy.
  • Hepatosplenomegaly.
  • Testicular enlargement.
  • Mediastinal mass in T-ALL (Superior mediastinal syndrome).

CNS manifestations
  • Headache.
  • Vomiting.
  • Nerve palsies.
  • Morphology:
    • Hypercellular bone marrow.
    • Lymphoblasts have more condensed chromatin, less conspicuous nucleoli, and scanty agranular cytoplasm than myeloblasts.
    • Cytochemistry: Myeloperoxidase (MPO) negative, sudan black negative.

Note: Myeloblasts are large cells with scanty blue cytoplasm, round, oval or irregular nuclei, fine chromatin, and multiple prominent nucleoli.

questions.text: Which of the following markers will be negative on immunophenotyping of a patient with early pre-B acute leukaemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) CD10¬†

Explanation:

CD10 and Cytoplasmic immunoglobulins (Cy Ig) are negative in early pre-B acute leukaemia but become positive in pre-B ALL.

Immunophenotyping of Acute Lymphocytic Leukemia (ALL):

Type of ALL

Immunophenotype

Early Pre-B ALL

TdT, DR, CD19, CD24¬†

Pre-B ALL

TdT, DR, CD10, CD19, CD20, CD24, Cy Ig

Common ALL

CD19+, CD10+/CALLA+

Mature B ALL

DR, CD19 CD20, CD24, Surface Ig

Pro-T ALL

CD3, CD7¬†

Pre-T ALL

TdT, CD2, CD3, CD4, CD5, CD7, CD8, CD34

Mature T ALL

CD2, CD7, TdT

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the prognosis of ALL?


	Adults have a worse prognosis as compared to children aged 2-9 years.
	White females have a good survival rate as compared to black males.
	The Philadelphia chromosome (t(9;22)) is associated with a favourable prognosis.
	Higher white blood cell counts at diagnosis are associated with a better prognosis.
	Hypodiploidy in B-ALL is associated with a better prognosis.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A)¬†3, 4 and 5

Explanation:

Prognostic factors associated with ALL:

Determinants

Favourable

Unfavourable

WBC/¬µL

<10,000

>1,00,000 (Statement D)

Age

2-9 years

<1 year, >10 years (Statement A)

Gender

Female

Male

Ethnicity

White (Statement B)

Black

Lymph node, liver, spleen enlargement

Absent

Present

Testicular enlargement

Absent

Present

CNS involvement

Absent

Present

FAB morphologic features

L1, early pre-B cell ALL

L3, Pre-B cell & mature B-cell ALL

Ploidy

Hyperdiploidy

Hypodiploidy (Statement E)

Cytogenetic markers

Trisomy 4, 10, 17, t(12;21)

t(9;22), t(4;11) (Statement C)

Remission states

<14 days

>14 days

¬†

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with fever, fatigue, and bone pain. On physical examination, there is notable hepatosplenomegaly and testicular enlargement. Laboratory findings show elevated white blood cell count and blasts on peripheral smear. Immunophenotyping reveals the presence of markers CD3, CD5, and CD10. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B)¬†T cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia
¬†

Explanation:
This young boy with elevated WBC counts and blast cells on a peripheral smear, combined with testicular involvement and positive CD3, CD5, and CD10, is most likely to have T-cell acute lymphocytic leukaemia (ALL).
Important features of different types of leukaemia:

¬†

ALL
¬†

AML

(Option A)

CML

(Option D)
¬†

(Option C)

(Option B)

-¬†

Middle-Elderly

Mutation

Loss of function PAX5, E2A, EBF

Gain of function NOTCH1

t(15:17) in M3,
t (8:21) in M2

t(9:22) BCR-ABL fusion gene.¬†

Prognosis

Good

Good¬†

Involvement

Decreased NAP/LAP score

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the M4 subtype of AML based on FAB classification is true?

choices.text: It is associated with t(8:21), called AML with maturation.
It is associated with t(15:17), called acute promyelocytic leukaemia
It is associated with CBF-MYH fusion, called acute myelomonocytic leukaemia
It is associated with MPO positivity, called AML without maturation.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C)¬†It is associated with CBF-MYH fusion, called acute myelomonocytic leukaemia

Explanation:

Acute myelocytic leukemia (M4) type, also called acute myelomonocytic leukaemia, is associated with the CBF-MYH fusion gene.

FAB classification of AML

Subtype

Name

Features

AML-M0

AML undifferentiated
  • MPO negative

AML-M1

AML without maturation (Option D)
  • MPO +

AML-M2

AML with maturation
(Option A)
  • Most common
  • t(8:21) RUNX1-RUNX1T1 fusion
  • Associated with chloroma.

AML-M3

Acute promyelocytic leukaemia
(Option B)
  • t(15:17) - PML-RARùõº fusion
  • Blocks promyelocyte ‚Üí myelocyte transformation
  • Bone marrow: Auer rods form criss-cross called faggot cell

  • Can cause DIC
  • PAS+

AML-M4

Acute myelomonocytic leukaemia
(Option C)
  • Associated with inv 16 and CBF-MYH fusion gene
  • Gums - gum hypertrophy
  • Skin - leukaemia cutis
  • MPO+, NSE +

AML-M5

Acute monocytic leukaemia
  • Gums - gum hypertrophy
  • Skin - leukaemia cutis
  • MPO-, NSE +

AML-M6

Acute erythroid leukaemia
  • Also called DI Guglielmo Disease
  • Diffuse PAS+, CD71

AML-M7

Acute megakaryocytic leukaemia
  • Bone Marrow aspiration gives a dry tap
  • PAS+, CD41 and CD61

¬†

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with fatigue, bruising, and intermittent fevers for the past few weeks. Physical examination reveals the following findings. Immunophenotyping of the biopsy specimen shows CD43 and MPO positivity. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) AML with maturation

¬†Explanation:

This young child with nonspecific systemic symptoms, MPO positivity, and an image showing orbital swelling and proptosis suggests chloroma associated with AML with maturation (AML-M2).

Chloroma:

  • A.k.a Myeloblastoma/Granulocytic Sarcoma.
  • It is not a benign tumour, but it has a greenish colour.
  • Site: Soft tissue involvement in orbit leads to proptosis.
  • Associated with AML M2 and M5.
  • Peripheral smear findings:
    • Myeloblasts.
    • Arbiskov cells: Atypical monocytes/macrophages.
  • Markers: MPO (green colour), CD 43, CD 45 and Lysozyme.

¬† ¬†

Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) (Option A): ALL mostly stains PAS and Acid phosphatase and are negative for CD43 and MPO.

Acute promyelocytic leukaemia (Option C): The¬†M3 subtype of Acute Myeloid Leukaemia (AML) is associated with disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) and PAS positivity.

Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma (Option D): Burkitt's lymphoma (non-Hodgkin lymphoma), is characterised by cervical lymphadenopathy, causes jaw swelling and CD19, 20, and PAX5 positivity.

¬†

¬†

¬†

¬†

questions.text: A 28-year-old female was admitted to the hospital with complaints of frequent nosebleeds, reports of sudden onset chest pain and dyspnea. On examination, she has petechiae and ecchymoses on her skin. Laboratory tests revealed WBC 15,000/¬µL, haemoglobin 8 g/dL, platelets 20,000/¬µL and elevated prothrombin time. A peripheral blood smear shows the following findings. Further testing confirms which of the following associated conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B)¬†t(15:17) translocation

Explanation:

This patient's history of sudden onset symptoms with pancytopenia, high prothrombin time, and Auer-rods on blood smear suggests disseminated intravascular coagulation secondary to acute promyelocytic leukaemia associated with t(15:17) translocation.

M3 AML/ Acute promyelocytic leukemia:

  • Genetics:
    • t(15:17) translocation causes PML-RARA (retinoic acid receptor alpha) fusion protein formation.
    • Blocks promyelocyte ‚Üí myelocyte maturation.
    • Diagnosis of choice: FISH
  • Smear findings:
    • Increased promyelocytes.
    • Auer Rods: Fused granules in promyelocytes
    • Faggot Cells: Auer rods with a crisscross pattern.
  • Laboratory:
    • Low hemoglobin and platelets.
    • > 20% blasts on peripheral and bone marrow smear
    • Stain: PAS +
    • CD markers: CD 13, 33 +
  • Complication: Disseminated intravascular coagulation therefore, chemotherapy is not recommended.
  • Treatment:
    • ATRA (All-trans-retinoic-acid) + As2O3 (arsenic trioxide)
    • Best prognosis among all AML.

t(12:21) translocation (Option A) is seen in ALL and has a good prognosis. They are negative for auer rods.

t(9:22) translocation (Option C):

  • Philadelphia chromosome associated with CML and ALL (worse prognosis).
    • CML: t(9;22) results in a BCR-ABL fusion protein of 210 kDa.
    • ALL: t(9;22) results in a BCR-ABL fusion protein of 190 kDa.
  • Presents with massive hepatosplenomegaly.
  • Labs show normal RBC with elevated TLC (>40,000) and platelet counts.
  • Peripheral smear reveals immature WBC with basophils called bone marrow appearance.

t(8:21) translocation (Option D):

  • t(8:21) translocation is seen in the M2 subtype of AML (most common).
  • Associated with chloroma.
  • The smear reveals > 10% mature myeloid cells, not Auer rods.

¬†

¬†

¬†

questions.text: Which of the following types of AML, according to the FAB classification, is associated with Down‚Äôs syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct answer:¬†C)¬†Acute megakaryocytic leukaemia

Explanation:

Acute megakaryoblastic leukaemia (AML M7) is notably associated with Down's syndrome.

Acute megakaryocytic leukaemia:

  • Least common type of AML.
  • The megakaryocytes release platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF), causing myelofibrosis.
  • It is the most common AML in Down‚Äôs syndrome and the most common type of leukemia in Down's syndrome is ALL.
  • Antibodies against megakaryocyte-specific markers (GPIIb/IIIa or vWF) can be seen.
  • Bone marrow aspiration yields a ‚Äòdry tap‚Äô due to fibrosis in the bone marrow.

¬†

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with a good prognosis according to WHO classification of AML?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) AML with recurrent genetic abnormality

Explanation:

AML defined by specific genetic abnormalities are associated with a good prognosis due to the presence of targetable mutations and the availability of specific therapies, such as ATRA for APL.

Examples include:

  • t(8;21) (RUNX1-RUNX1T1)
  • inv(16) CBFB-MYH11
  • t(15;17) PML-RARA

WHO Classification of AML:

  1. AML with Recurrent Genetic Abnormalities (good prognosis):
    • t(8;21)(q22;q22.1); RUNX1-RUNX1T1
    • inv(16) (CBFB-MYH11)
    • t(15;17)(q24.1;q21.1); PML-RARA.
    • t(1;22)
  2. AML with Myelodysplasia-Related Changes (bad prognosis)
  3. Therapy-Related Myeloid Neoplasms (bad prognosis)
  4. AML, Not Otherwise Specified (NOS) (bad prognosis)
    • AML with minimal differentiation
    • AML without maturation
    • AML with myelocytic maturation
    • AML with myelomonocytic maturation.
    • AML with monocytic maturation.
    • AML with erythroid maturation.
    • AML with megakaryocytic maturation.
  5. AML associated with Down's syndrome - AMLM7.

¬†

questions.text: What is the most likely immunophenotype associated with the condition indicated by the peripheral blood smear shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) CD13+, CD33+, CD34+, HLA-DR+

Explanation:

The peripheral smear shows myeloblasts (large, irregularly shaped cells with prominent nuclei and moderately granular cytoplasm), and needle-like inclusions in the cytoplasm of blasts (Auer rods), suggesting acute myeloid leukaemia (AML). The immunophenotype associated with AML is CD13+, CD33+, CD34+, and HLA-DR+.

  • AML is characterised by the presence of myeloid lineage markers.
  • CD13, CD33, and CD34 are commonly expressed on AML blasts.
  • Additionally, the presence of HLA-DR is typical in AML immunophenotyping.

CD19+, CD20-, CD22+, CD79a- (Option B):

  • This immunophenotyping pattern is characteristic of B-cell ALL.
  • In B-ALL, blasts typically express B-cell markers such as CD19, CD22, and CD79a.
  • CD20 expression is variable but often negative in B-ALL.

CD3+, CD4+, CD8+, CD5- (Option C):

  • This immunophenotyping pattern is indicative of T-cell ALL.
  • In T-ALL, blasts express T-cell markers such as CD3, CD4, CD8, and CD5, reflecting their origin from T-cell precursors.

CD10+, CD19+, CD20+, CD22- (Option D):

  • This immunophenotyping pattern is suggestive of B-cell Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (B-CLL).
  • In B-CLL, leukemic cells express B-cell markers such as CD19, CD20, and CD22.
  • CD10 expression is variable but often present in B-CLL cases.

¬†

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presented with fatigue, easy bruising, and recurrent infections over the past few months. On examination, there is mild splenomegaly, but no lymphadenopathy is noted. Laboratory tests reveal pancytopenia. A peripheral blood smear shows normocytic normochromic red blood cells and no blast cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Aleukemic leukaemia

Explanation:

  • In this scenario, the patient presents with pancytopenia, fatigue, easy bruising, and recurrent infections. The absence of blast cells in the peripheral smear despite the presence of cytopenias suggests aleukemic leukaemia.
  • Aleukemic leukaemia or aleukemic leukaemia cutis is leukaemia without circulating blast cells in the peripheral blood. While blast cells may be absent in the peripheral smear, they can still be present in the bone marrow. The malignant white cells invade the skin before they appear in the peripheral blood or bone marrow.
  • Patients may present with symptoms similar to other types of leukaemia, including fatigue, weakness, fever, weight loss, and easy bruising or bleeding.
  • Diagnosis requires a high index of suspicion, as the absence of blast cells in the peripheral blood smear can make it challenging to identify.
  • A bone marrow biopsy may reveal the presence of leukaemia cells, aiding in diagnosis.

Aplastic anemia (Option A):

  • Aplastic anaemia is characterised by pancytopenia (low red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets) due to bone marrow failure.
  • Unlike leukaemia, it does not involve the overproduction of immature cells (blast cells) and does not typically present with blasts on peripheral smears.

Myelodysplasia (Option B):

  • Myelodysplasia, or myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS), is a group of blood disorders characterised by abnormal development and function of blood-forming cells in the bone marrow.
  • In MDS, the bone marrow produces immature or defective blood cells that may not function properly.

Myeloproliferative disorder (Option D):

  • Myeloproliferative disorders (MPDs) are a group of conditions characterised by excessive production of mature blood cells.
  • Unlike leukaemia, MPDs do not typically present with pancytopenia (reduced levels of all blood cell types) and do not involve the overproduction of blast cells seen in leukaemia.

¬†
